items.title: Add caret-animation

items.content_html:
would be nice to have caniuse.com/udp

afaik, no mainstream browser has full UDP support (raw UDP support)
only HTTP/3 (HTTP over QUIC) which is based on UDP

UDP is required for

  • bittorrent: UDP trackers, DHT, uTP
  • online games

UDP support is part of github.com/WICG/direct-sockets

alternatives

  • Web Sockets
  • WebRTC Peer-to-peer connections
  • WebTransport

afaik, no mainstream browser has full UDP support (raw UDP support)

IPFS (bittorrent over TCP) is a workaround for this limitation, but IPFS is slow
so the actual solution would be web browsers with full UDP support

IPFS docs on QUIC: docs.libp2p.io/concepts/transports/quic/

QUIC is a new transport protocol that provides an always-encrypted, stream-multiplexed connection built on top of UDP.

In addition to defining the QUIC transport, the IETF also standardized a new version of HTTP that runs on top of QUIC

related

  • WebSockets, UDP, and benchmarks
    • It's likely arbitrary UDP connections will never be part of any web specification because of security concerns. The closest thing to what you're after will likely come as part of WebRTC and it's associated JSEP protocol.
  • How to talk to UDP sockets with HTML5?
  • chrome apps: chrome.sockets.udp
  • webtorrent/webtorrent#288
items.title: udp: add feature

items.content_html:
It may very well be the case that caniuse doesn't bother tracking WICG standards, in which case, please close this issue and disregard it.

Otherwise, major browsers have already implemented this feature which allows greater levels of zstd and brotli compression via compression dictionaries. It's a new standard that has been under discussion and in development for about one or two years. I understand that it was released in Chrome 130 just a couple days ago.

See https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-httpbis-compression-dictionary/ and https://github.com/WICG/compression-dictionary-transport
items.title: Add WICG/compression-dictionary-transport

items.title: Safe Assignment Operator

items.content_html:
https://www.bram.us/2024/07/11/feature-detect-css-starting-style-support/:

While in theory you could use @supports at-rule() for this, in practice you can't because it has no browser support (😭).

https://www.bram.us/2022/01/20/detect-at-rule-support-with-the-at-rule-function/:

the CSS Working Group just decided to introduce a new function that be used in conjunction with @supports: at-rule().

With it, we can feature detect at-rule support as follows:

@supports at-rule(@foo) {
  /* @foo is supported */
}
  • WebKit/Safari: Issue #235400
  • Gecko/Firefox: Issue #1751188
  • Blink/Chromium: Issue #1289224

I feel like it's very likely that this will come via MDN, but as usual just keeping track 🤓
items.title: Add `@supports at-rule`

items.content_html:
This could be broken out into multiple features:

  • Symbol.dispose
  • Symbol.asyncDispose
  • using syntax
  • await using syntax
  • DisposableStack
  • AsyncDisposableStack

Spec: https://github.com/tc39/proposal-explicit-resource-management

Looks like Chrome is shipping Symbol.dispose, but no one is shipping anything else.
items.title: Feature request: tc39 Explicit Resource Management

items.content_html:
The JavaScript Promise Integration specification is an in-progress specification intended to make it easier for applications written in Wasm to perform synchronous IO on non-blocking runtimes like the browser.

References

  • WebAssembly/js-promise-integration (specification)
  • Chrome blog: Introducing the WebAssembly JavaScript Promise Integration API
  • Chrome blog: WebAssembly JSPI is going to origin trial
  • Firefox JSPI specification position (positive)
  • Firefox bugzilla tracking issue
items.title: Track the status of the JavaScript Promise Integration specification

items.content_html: Hybrid key exchange in SSL handshake using ML-KEM in addition to default already has significant usage thanks to Google and Cloudflare. It appears to only be supported currently in TLS 1.3 but is intended for TLS 1.2 as well.
items.title: X25519Kyber768 Hybrid Post-Quantum Key Exchange for HTTPS

items.content_html:
New events were released for scroll snaps. Would be nice to have this in caniuse:

https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/-naLTco_PEo/m/GwL4OA6dAQAJ
items.title: Snap Events: scrollsnapchange and scrollsnapchanging

items.content_html:
CanIuse.com has a lot of the newer pieces of WASM. Chrome has had WasmGC enabled by default since October 2023. This is a major component of Wasm adoption that will start enabling GC languages to compile to Wasm, so it would be great for this to be tracked.

Spec is here: https://github.com/WebAssembly/gc
items.title: [Request] Please add Web Assembly Garbage Collection (WasmGC)

  • https://chromestatus.com/feature/4631882616012800

This spec requires large amounts of work to section it and word it in ways that are normative. It is currently a very rough draft.

Hence "…maybe eventually"
items.title: Add Web Preferences API …maybe eventually

items.content_html:
I couldn't find any documentation on these css properties that allow styling of HTML5 audio (and I assume video). I can confirm they work in Chromium based browsers but can't really find any other information on them.

This is the full list:

- audio::-webkit-media-controls-panel
- audio::-webkit-media-controls-mute-button
- audio::-webkit-media-controls-play-button
- audio::-webkit-media-controls-timeline-container
- audio::-webkit-media-controls-current-time-display
- audio::-webkit-media-controls-time-remaining-display
- audio::-webkit-media-controls-timeline
- audio::-webkit-media-controls-volume-slider-container
- audio::-webkit-media-controls-volume-slider
- audio::-webkit-media-controls-seek-back-button
- audio::-webkit-media-controls-seek-forward-button
- audio::-webkit-media-controls-fullscreen-button
- audio::-webkit-media-controls-rewind-button
- audio::-webkit-media-controls-return-to-realtime-button
- audio::-webkit-media-controls-toggle-closed-captions-button

This blog post documents the functionality quite neatly.
items.title: CSS property media-controls-panel
